fields.description:
When you manually create a new review in Crucible from code already committed, it pulls in the commit message to populate the Objectives, along with the Git hash. When you use the +review smart commit tag to create a new review, it puts the commit message into the review title but not the objectives. For long commit messages, you can't see all of the text in the title. So the only way to understand the context of the commit is to open a modified file, search for the commit hash, and open that commit to see the entire message.

Rather than being able to hover over the review title to get all of the text (which I suppose would be nice too), the +review smart commit could also populate the objectives if it's a new review.
fields.summary: Review smart commit should populate Crucible Objectives

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# {{Source > Repo > Reports}}.
# Choose *Line* as *Chart Type*.
# Choose a "Date Range" (i.e 2012-04-01 - 2012-04-30).
# Hit "Apply".

That will generate a graph but the Pie and Change options are disabled (and the Date Range information entered is removed).

All filters also fail to modify graph data.

Workaround: Hack the URL directly:
{noformat}
http://<Fisheye_Base_URL>/chart/~charttype=<Chart Type Goes Here>,stacktype=None/<Repository Name Goes Here>
{noformat}

fields.description:
Some ideas for the Fecru zip package:

# Sometimes the user forget to copy the jar driver file to the lib folder. I suggest to leave all DB Drivers (mysql-connector-java-5.1.10.jar, ojdbc5-11gR2.jar, postgresql-8.4-701.jdbc3.jar and jtds-1.2.5.jar) inside the lib directory (and not inside lib/dbdrivers/*).
# Don't let customers run the Set-up Wizard if they haven't defined a <FISHEYE_INST> variable before (like it happens on JIRA).
# We should create and include a script (for linux) so the customers be able to start/stop/restart Fecru as a Linux service. For instance, copy the script to /etc/init.d/ and add a link to the /etc/rc.X/SXXFecru so it can get started automatically. 
# On Windows boxes we should offer a msi package so it can be already shipped as a service, what would avoid a lot of issues of the type "Can´t get Fisheye running as a Service with Wrapper".

Thank you in advance.

Cheers,
*Douglas Fabretti*
*Atlassian Support*

fields.description:
EyeQL should have a way to query merged SVN revisions vs. native to the branch, and produce a difference between two branches presenting revisions missing in selected branch.
Presently EyeQL doesn’t distinguish (for SVN) native revision (change made in the branch) from a revision created as a result of merger.
There are mixed case situations when a revision includes both native changes and merged revisions yet from reconciliation point of view those should be accounted for as merged revisions as well.

SVN merged revision gets new revision number but SVN metadata and SVN log command resulting xml structure clearly indicate what branch (path) and revision the merged copy comes from.
Introduction of new 'merged' (vs. modified or added) qualifier should limit query return to post-branching (just like modified) merged (vs. native) revision scope.
it’s essential that return includes original revision and path along with newly created revision in result of merger.
New revision may have several original revisions included so its possible that native revision will be listed several times along with every merged revision.

In order to reconcile 2 branches 2 reports would be necessary to run
1.	Merged revisions report 
2.	Partially or non-merged revisions report

Below are query examples (totally made up) 

--- list revisions modified in A but not merged into B ---
select revisions from dir "/" 
where modified on branch A and not merged on branch B
order by date desc
group by csid
return count(revisions), csid, comment, author

--- list revisions modified in A and merged into B ---
select revisions from dir "/" 
where modified on branch A and merged on branch B
order by date desc
group by csid
return count(revisions), csid, comment, author
my 'toy' query (albeit not resolving my issue) does show the report in format very close to what I envision:
•	Row Count as link to changeset group contents
•	Changeset ID as link to the change set and set size displayed as well.
•	Comment with JIRA issue link URL.
Here's the query:
select revisions from dir "/" 
where 
modified on branch A or
modified on branch B
order by date desc
group by csid
return count(revisions), csid, comment, author
fields.summary: EyeQL to find merge breaks between related branches

group by changeset return csid, author, date, comment, count(revisions), count(distinct path), sum(linesAdded), sum(linesRemoved)
{noformat}

It returns some results as expected. So there aren't any parsing errors here.

If I *left-click* on the 'Link to this search' link, a blank page is displayed. I think this is *somewhat expected*, but some customers may think another page with some content should be displayed.

I think this is *somewhat expected* because, as far as I can understand, the purpose of the 'Link to this search' link isn't to left-click on it and go to another screen, but to *right-click* on it and copy the link address and paste it elsewhere, so the same search and search results can be visited another time, by clicking on the link copied.

And here I can see some strange behaviors. If I copy the resulting link address and paste it in a:

* Google Chrome 18.0.1025.162 window, I get a blank screen.
* Mozilla Firefox 11.0 window, I get a blank screen.
* Internet Explorer 9.0.8112.16421 window, a search results page is displayed, however it reports an error:
{noformat}
There was a problem with your search

Search error:
error parsing query: expecting '"', found '7'
{noformat}

This works like a charm if I use a small EyeQL, such as:
{noformat}
select revisions from dir "/" where comment =~ "JRA-1|JRA-2|JRA-3|JRA-4|JRA-5" group by changeset return csid, author, date, comment, count(revisions), count(distinct path), sum(linesAdded), sum(linesRemoved)
{noformat}
Then right-click on 'Link to this search', copy the link address and paste it on the same browsers/versions.

Note that the only difference between the huge and the small EyeQL are the number of {{comment}} filters.

Maybe the 'Link to this search' URL generated is not being generated correctly when it comes to huge EyeQL's?

No errors were reported in the logs.
fields.summary: Huge EyeQL - Prevent the use of "Link to this search" when the query is too long

fields.description:
When using a custom authenticator, Fisheye will

1. query the database for a user with the entered username
2. if none is found, it will query the custom authenticator
3. if the custom authenticator returns an authtoken, it will create a user in the database based on the username in the authtoken. (NOT the entered username)

This is a problem if the username returned by the authenticator is different to the username entered.  On next login, this will happen:

1. database will be queried for entered username
2. authenticator will be queried
3. will attempt to create user again, but will fail and blow up because user already exists.

Ideally we should check if the user with the username returned by the authenticator exists before trying to create it again.
fields.summary: Fisheye does not allow username returned by AuthToken to be different from username entered by user

fields.description:
When the FishEye/Crucible administrator is adding an existing repository and is currently on *'Add Repository - Page 2 of 3'* screen:

* It could be listed below the repository *URL / Location﻿* field all the valid protocols ordered by speed (from fastest to slowest), depending on the repository type he chose on *'Add Repository - Page 1 of 3'* screen, with links instructing him on how to configure the repository to use each protocol type, and suggest him to try to use the fastest protocol the possible.

When the FishEye/Crucible administrator is creating a new repository:
* Nowadays only Git repositories can be created. When the administrator clicks the *'Create'﻿* button, the repository is automatically created using http:// protocol. However, Git can use file:// protocol as well as ssh:// and https:// (which are slower than file://, of course). 
Why isn't the Git repository being created using file:// protocol, which is the fastest?
fields.summary: Ensure the fastest network protocol is being used when adding or creating repositories

fields.description:
An issue has been reported by a customer of sporadic failure of smart commits for CVS.  I have investigated the cause and have found that the changeset that is attached to the event fired to the smart commit module is incorrect.

Behaviour observed:
com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.CommitNotificationRepositoryListener line 192 calls:
getChangeSets(commitNotification, repositoryHandle, engine.getRevisionCache());

 * on the first commit that is observed after fisheye has started up, no changeset is returned, and no event is fired
 * for subsequent commits that are observed, the changeset prior to the changeset that was just committed is returned

Example scenario and outcome:
1. Fisheye is started from a stopped state
2. A commit is made to the CVS repository
 - Fisheye gives this commit the identifier MAIN:rstephens:20120418043208
 - no events are fired in response to this commit
3. Another commit is made to the CVS repository
 - Fisheye gives this commit the identifier MAIN:rstephens:20120418043315
 - an event is fired for commit MAIN:rstephens:20120418043208

Further information to come.

*Update - 30/04:* Second customer reports similar problems, this time with a P4 repo. See https://support.atlassian.com/browse/FSH-8815

*Please check all repo types when addressing this issue*

*Update - 7/5:* This relates specifically to CVS.  Testing confirmed this behaviour is not present for either Perforce or Subversion. -rstephens
fields.summary: Commit hook events are fired with incorrect changesets for CVS

fields.description:
This is something that might help Support while investigating integration issues. 

This might include information such as authentication method (Trusted Applications, OAuth, Basic Access), the JIRA and FishEye/Crucible mappings between JIRA projects and FishEye repositories / Crucible projects, any URL Patterns and IP Patterns defined in the configuration and anything else that relates to integration setup.

This will help bring down the ORT on integration tickets, as exchanging emails to confirm the basic setup takes a lot of time. 
Sometimes a screenshare helps too, but its not the most time-effective solution.

Also the {{FISHEYE_HOME/config.xml}} can be very confusing to understand. It would be good to have a document explaining the different integration related components there and what to look out for when troubleshooting such cases.

fields.description:
Currently, FishEye supports both case sensitive, and case insensitive usernames.

This is fundamentally flawed, as a user can toggle between these via the admin screen.

We suggest deprecating this toggle, and making FishEye support case insensitive usernames only.

See also: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-6107
fields.summary: Only support case insensitive usernames

fields.description:
This NPE happens when loading an Application Link:
{noformat}
2012-04-16 11:22:44,756 INFO  [btpool0-67 ] fisheye.app TotalityFilter-logExceptionDetails - Exception "null" (java.lang.NullPointerException) while processing "/plugins/servlet/applinks/auth/conf/trusted/inbound-ual/f1245475-74c9-3e36-947f-d9e7ee964588" (Referer:"https://fisheye.mcdean.com/plugins/servlet/applinks/auth/conf/config-tabs")
java.lang.NullPointerException
    at com.atlassian.applinks.core.auth.trusted.ProviderConfigurationServlet.render(ProviderConfigurationServlet.java:280)
{noformat}

There's no apparent reason why this issue occurs, but seems to happen after a restart/upgrade.

One current workaround is to shutdown FishEye, remove the Application Links from {{config.xml}} and re-establish the link.

If this does not resolve the problem, please ensure to bypass any proxies (both forwarding and reverse) that are being used by the application. This can be done by rolling back the changes in [Configuring the FishEye web server|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Configuring+the+FishEye+web+server] and [Configuring Outgoing Web Proxy Support for FishEye or Crucible|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Configuring+Outgoing+Web+Proxy+Support+for+FishEye+or+Crucible].
fields.summary: NPE while loading Application Link

fields.description:
When an Application Link is deleted in FishEye side, trash remains in {{FISHEYE_HOME/config.xml}}. This sometimes block users from creating a new project links, and also throws an error when trying to delete any new Application Links.

By trash, I mean related {{<property>}} elements and also {{<trustedApplication>}} elements and their inner elements. When this problem happens, [users need to delete these elements by hand and restart the instance|http://confluence.atlassian.com/x/HZILE], which is not good. FishEye must delete all elements from {{FISHEYE_HOME/config.xml}} that are related to that Application Link being deleted using the web interface.
fields.summary: When an Application Link is deleted in FishEye side, trash remains in config.xml

fields.description:
Problems synchronizing with JIRA user base can cause many errors like this:
{noformat}
2012-04-16 17:38:08,441 WARN  [btpool0-16 ] fisheye.app LoginServlet-login - error checking password
com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.DbException: User named "username" already exists.
{noformat}

FishEye is case sensitive. JIRA now has Crowd embedded and hence inherited Crowd's case insensitiveness. This is the root cause of the problem.

The suggestion here is to force all usernames to be lowercased by default, instead of having to do this manually by following this document:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Forcing+Imported+Usernames+to+be+Lowercase
fields.summary: Problems synchronizing with JIRA user base

fields.description:
If the instances are on the same server, there's no need to use proxy / SSL between the instances. 
Proxy / SSL settings can be bypassed in cases like this by using localhost instead. 

Both FishEye/Crucible and JIRA should show a warning to the user, suggesting him to localhost instead.
fields.summary: When adding an Application Link, with the instances on the same server, there is no need to use proxy / SSL

fields.description:
A couple of things can cause the message:
_Error creating subtask in JIRA - Unknown error creating subtask for issue ABC-1234 - null_

# The user logged in Crucible may not exist in JIRA, or does not have permissions to create issues in that JIRA project. 
*Probable solution:*
## Crucible could use [this JIRA REST API command|http://docs.atlassian.com/jira/REST/latest/#id2475676] in order to check if the user exists in JIRA.
## Improve [this JIRA REST API command|http://docs.atlassian.com/jira/REST/latest/#id2476210] in order to retrieve which permission scheme the JIRA project is using, each kind of permission of that permission scheme, and all users/groups/roles allowed on each kind of permission. This would allow checking (combined with the [REST API command above|http://docs.atlassian.com/jira/REST/latest/#id2475676]) if the user logged in has the expected permissions on the JIRA project linked to the Crucible project in question.
## Display a friendly message to the customer, with the results of the above two tests and links to the JIRA instance's [create new user|http://localhost:8080/secure/admin/user/AddUser!default.jspa] page and to the [project permission scheme|http://localhost:8080/plugins/servlet/project-config/JRA/permissions] page.
# The Crucible review the user is trying to create JIRA issues from may not have a JIRA issue linked to it.
*Probable solution:*
## Use [this Crucible REST API|http://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/wadl/crucible.html#d2e748] to check if the Crucible review has a JIRA issue key linked to it. The information will be on the element {{<jiraIssueKey>}}.
## Display a friendly message to the customer, with the results of the above test and a link to the Crucible review in edit mode focusing in the *Linked Issue* field.
# A 'Closed' JIRA ticket is linked to the Crucible review the user is trying to create JIRA sub-tasks from. This is impossible yet: [CRUC-3956|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-3956]
*Probable solution:*
## Use [this Crucible REST API|http://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/wadl/crucible.html#d2e748] to retrieve which JIRA issue is linked to that Crucible review.
## With the JIRA issue key in hands, use [this JIRA REST API command|http://docs.atlassian.com/jira/REST/latest/#id2474348] to retrieve the JIRA issue {{Status}} information and check if it's valid.
## Display a friendly message to the customer, with the results of the above test and a link to the JIRA issue in question so the customer can transition the JIRA issue to a valid state, or with a link to the [JIRA's Create New Issue|http://localhost:8080/secure/CreateIssue!default.jspa] page. If a new JIRA issue is created, this new JIRA issue should be set in the Crucible review's *Linked Issue* field.
# The JIRA issue has mandatory custom fields that must be filled at the moment of issue creation. As Crucible is not aware of these JIRA custom fields, this can be causing the error. This bug was already reported: [CRUC-2667|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-2667]
*Probable solution:*
## Use [this JIRA REST API command|http://docs.atlassian.com/jira/REST/latest/#id2474348] to retrieve the issue fields of the JIRA issue linked to that Crucible review and check whether any of these fields is a custom *required* field.
## Display a friendly message to the customer, with the results of the above test and a link to the correct *Field Configuration* in JIRA, where the customer is allowed to change the required custom fields to optional.

fields.description:
Sometimes users see this error message:

_Sorry, there are no links available when using anonymous access, check the permission configuration of the remote application._

At least two things can cause it:
* There's a missing IP address in the Trusted Application configured between JIRA and FishEye/Crucible. A message like this is thrown in the logs:
{noformat}
Error handling trusted applications authentication attempt:BAD_REMOTE_IP; Request not allowed from IP address: {0}; ["123.45.67.89"]
{noformat}
** To solve this, the application should enforce that the user needs to fill in the *IP Patterns* fields correctly. If the expected IP is mentioned in the logs, it could be suggested in the web interface as well.

* User may not be logged in FishEye / Crucible with a valid admin user (only with the global admin password), and is trying to create a project link between a FishEye repository or Crucible project with a JIRA project, then no user can be authenticated in JIRA side in order to retrieve the JIRA projects.
** To solve this, before creating / modifying an Application Link or Project Link, FishEye/Crucible must check if an administrator is logged in (i.e., the user is not only using the global admin password).
fields.summary: Application Links showing the same error message for different root causes

fields.description:
After adding an Application Link between JIRA and FishEye using Trusted Applications, the Trusted Applications will show *'Configured'* status for both Incoming and Outgoing Authentication. However, the integration is *incomplete*, and the customer thinks it's complete.

The suggestions are:
*Outgoing Authentication:*
* *"IP Patterns"* field could be more clear about which IP addresses the customer should add, which should be the IP addresses of their *FishEye/Crucible* site.
* *"URL Patterns"* field is never filled, at least for FECRU x JIRA integration. Why is it displayed?

*Incoming Authentication:*
* *"IP Patterns"* field could be more clear about which IP addresses the customer should add, which should be the IP addresses of their *JIRA* site.
* *"URL Patterns"* field could be automatically filled, as the values are fixed:
{noformat}
/secure/CreateSubTaskIssueDetails.jspa
/browse/
/rest
/plugins/servlet/applinks/whoami
/plugins/servlet/streams
/rpc/soap
/sr/jira.issueviews:searchrequest
/secure/RunPortlet
{noformat}
Even better, as the field must always contain these values, maybe the field could never be displayed to the customer. It could be configured programmatically.
fields.summary: Improve user experience when configuring Trusted Applications

fields.description:
There are at least 2 issues with the DefaultUserManager used in FishEye/Crucible regarding thread safety. The first one has been seen in practice, the second one however has not.


h3. importUser race condition
It is possible that 2 threads can enter any of the getOrImportXXX methods that do an upfront check for the existence of a User. If the user doesn't exist, then the user is imported. It is possible for 2 threads to both try and import a user, where both see the user doesn't exist first, then 1 will fail if it loses the race to create the user.

Seen in studio:

{code}
012-04-02 00:07:11,980 INFO  [btpool0-4 ] fisheye.app DefaultUserManager-importUser - auto-import user: "mlandis@5amsolutions.com"
2012-04-02 00:07:11,982 INFO  [btpool0-7 ] fisheye.app DefaultUserManager-importUser - auto-import user: "mlandis@5amsolutions.com"
2012-04-02 00:07:12,067 INFO  [btpool0-9 ] fisheye.app DefaultUserManager-importUser - auto-import user: "mlandis@5amsolutions.com"
2012-04-02 00:07:12,089 WARN  [btpool0-7 ] fisheye.app UserDetector-tryRequestDelegatedLogin - problem logging user delegated 
com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.DbException: User named "mlandis@5amsolutions.com" already exists.
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.DefaultUserManager$19.write(DefaultUserManager.java:1251)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.DefaultUserManager$19.write(DefaultUserManager.java:1245)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.config.DB0Handle.write(DB0Handle.java:96)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.DefaultUserManager.addUserImpl(DefaultUserManager.java:1245)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.DefaultUserManager.importUser(DefaultUserManager.java:634)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.DefaultUserManager.getOrImportDelegatedUser(DefaultUserManager.java:594)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.DefaultUserManager.tryRequestDelegatedLogin(DefaultUserManager.java:762)

{code}



h3. the mAuth member variable is not protected from multiple threads

It is possible for the importUser() method to see a null mAuth member variable if the reload method is called during the import of a user.
fields.summary: Thread (un)safety of DefaultUserManager.java...

fields.description:
At present we do not store the details of perforce branches, only their modification times. This means that on startup we need to do "branch -o" on every branch, even those which we know haven't changed, or which may not even be in the repo we are scanning.

To improve the speed of the first scan after startup, we should persist the branch details, so that only the branch update times and any changed branches need to be retrieved from the repository.

*Note well* that the first startup after upgrading to a version of FishEye/Crucible containing this bug fix will *not* be faster than previously, as the branches will still need to be loaded. Subsequent startups will be faster.
fields.summary: Store Perforce Branch Details

fields.description:
JIRA has a CSV import tool that allows the bulk creation of Projects simply by uploading a CSV with columns for project key, project name/description, username of the project owner, etc.

We should have the same feature in FishEye. I am in the middle of a migration from a Collabnet TeamForge server with 60+ projects and 130+ individual SVN repositories, and there was no way I was going to type these into FishEye one by one.

I solved this by going to SQL Server and inserting the records for my 60 projects directly. Since I already had a list of all 60 projects, it only took a minute to write a regular expression to build the 60 SQL Insert statements.

In order to create the 130 repositories I had to discover (the hard way) that repositories are not registered in the database, instead they are kept in an XML file. I used a similar approach: I had a list of the repository URLs I wanted to create, with their usernames, passwords, etc. With about 5 minutes of regular expressions I was able to build the XML that would register these repositories, I pasted it into the XML config file, restarted FishEye and bang! 130 repositories registered successfully.

If this was an ideal world, I would like to be able to create these hundreds of repositories by uploading a CSV or something like that. Also, I would find it useful if I could create Application links to both JIRA and Confluence, right now I have no choice but to link each of the 60 projects and each of the 130 repositories by hand, that's two links times 190 items!
fields.summary: Allow bulk creation of Repositories/Projects through CSV

fields.description:
Currently it is only possible to generate a "Review Coverage Report" on selected repositories in FishEye by selecting the following path:

Source -> \{Repository} -> Reports -> Review Coverage

I would like to see that it would be possible to generate a "Review Coverage Report" on Project Level. This Review Coverage report would show the consolidated statistics from the repositories associated to the selected project.

Suggested path for this functionality would be:
 Projects-> \{Project} -> Reports -> Review Coverage

With this functionality it would become much easier to compare the review coverage percentages over time for different projects without the hassle of consolidating these numbers manually. This is in particularly interesting when a lot of repositories are associated with a project.
fields.summary: Review Coverage Reports on Project Level

fields.description:
Investigate the impact on a server of bumping max-threads from its current default of 20, to something higher.

With servers now running with more RAM and CPUs than previously, allowing more concurrent web requests could prevent a bottleneck in some cases.

We should investigate what impact 150 web-requests will have on overall server performance however.

When FishEye's static content is served Jetty instead of apache or nginx, then more threads available to Jetty can have an impact on throughput.

*NB: this change will only affect new installations. Customers upgrading can manually bump the thread count by setting the max-threads attribute on the web-server element in config.xml*

fields.description:
We have identified and fixed a vulnerability in FishEye/Crucible that results from the way third-party XML parsers are used in FishEye/Crucible.

This vulnerability allows an attacker to:

*    Execute denial of service attacks against the FishEye and Crucible server, and
*    Read all local files readable to the system user under which FishEye and Crucible runs.

An attacker does not need to have an account with the affected FishEye or Crucible server to exploit this vulnerability.
All versions of FishEye/Crucible up to and including 2.7.11 are affected.

Fixed versions of FishEye/Crucible are:
* FishEye and Crucible 2.7.12 for FishEye and Crucible 2.7.11
* FishEye and Crucible 2.6.8 for FishEye and Crucible 2.6.7
* FishEye and Crucible 2.5.8 for FishEye and Crucible 2.5.7

There are no patches available.

This issue is reported in our security advisories on these pages:
FishEye: http://confluence.atlassian.com/x/jgK7E
Crucible: http://confluence.atlassian.com/x/mQK7E
fields.summary: FishEye XML Vulnerability

fields.description:
I would assume that this is an issue for source control products other than Subversion, but at least for that...

If a Subversion log message is entered and subsequently scanned in Fisheye, any edits to that log message will not be reflected in Fisheye unless one goes through the expensive process of reindexing and flushing the cache in Fisheye. See the following knowledgebase...

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHKB/Updates+to+log+messages+for+SVN+changesets+not+showing+in+JIRA+FishEye+plugin

So a JIRA defect will not get linked to the revision through the Fisheye plugin based on the edited comment.

I understand the logic behind not automatically scanning to pick up all possible edits to revision log messages. That would not be efficient.  However, it would be really nice to have a method in Fisheye to edit the cached revision message there as well so that JIRA can properly indicate the source involved in resolution.  It would be the user's responsibility to also update Subversion in case the Fisheye cache were ever flushed and rebuilt, but at least until that time there would still be a method of linking the JIRA issue to its relevant source.
fields.summary: Need a method to modify the cached source repository revision log message in Fisheye so the source can be linked to JIRA through the plugin.

fields.description:
The customer wants to limit access to a project by using Review Participants roles having already assigned users and groups to applicable roles via project permission schemes.  When it came time to modify permissions for viewing the project (Administration > Security Settings > Permission Schemes > "edit" (Name - default) > "edit" (View - Permissions) ), the customer just ticked the check-box of "Reviewer", making all other fields blank -- no other boxes checked (see attached: project_permissions_view.png).

In addition, the error that resulted when clicking on the project should reflect the lack of permission to view the project rather than the current note:  "The requested resource cannot be found."
See attached "error_msg.png"

The log currently shows the following:
{noformat}
2014-08-26 09:39:50,979 DEBUG [qtp445185455-1427 ] fisheye ProfilingServletFilter-logRequest - start request GET /project/CR sessionid=bf0v49jubozf1dpgl4v8ykz32
2014-08-26 09:39:51,164 DEBUG [qtp445185455-1427 ] fisheye ProjectPageAction-validate - permission denied for CR
2014-08-26 09:39:51,165 INFO  [qtp445185455-1427 ] fisheye ServletUtils-send404 - 404: No such project referer=http://localhost:8060/project/CR
{noformat}

*Workaround*
# Create a group which will be allowed to view the reviews in the project.
# Add the users to who you want to give access in this group.
# Edit the *View* permission of your permission scheme, adding this group as allowed.

*OR*

# Edit the *View* permission, adding the Individuals to who you want to give access.
fields.summary: 'Review Participants' roles are not used in determining the visibility of a project

fields.description:
Relates to:
https://support.atlassian.com/browse/FSH-8423

This issue was brought to our attention by a customer who tried to create users in FE (with Auth = Crowd) and found that after synchronization those users would disappear.  It seems like the users shouldn't have been deleted, rather that the users should have been created in Crowd.
fields.summary: Consider removing Crowd Auth and LDAP Auth from dropdown when creating users in FishEye (was: Authentication Sync (or Re-Sync) Deletes Users Created Only in FE)

fields.description:
When we merge from one branch to another, git adds a "merge commit" to record the merge. This commit will only directly contain changes that were made to resolve merge conflicts (if any), but it will also reference the commits that were merged from one branch to another.

Fisheye however, doesn't show any of the commits that were merged into the new branch as part of the merge operation. Not only is this a bit rubbish when trying to view the repository, it also makes it very difficult to create a Crucible review for the merge.

In the end, I worked around it by using {{git show -m HASH}} to produce a diff including all the merged commits (if git CLI can do it, then Fisheye should be able to!), and uploaded this to Crucible manually.
fields.summary: Support for git/mercurial merge commits

fields.description:
Hi, recently we make a mistake in crowd where we had fisheye-users fully populated and running from a delegated auth directory and we imported new users into that from Active Directory.  The mistake was that we checked the overwrite feature in the user import.  What this did was to leave fisheye-users empty.  We fixed this in about 10 mins.  During that time fisheye decided to rename all of the users that had been moved out of fisheye-users as username_old1.  Then when it saw the users in fisheye-users group again, it created new users.

It might be best if Fisheye/crucible would only move users in/out of groups and never rename them.
fields.summary: Fisheye should not rename users if group membership in fisheye-users changes

fields.summary: Display revision numbers for a folder

fields.description:
FishEye may spend a lot of time matching git content hashes to revisions. This is necessary because git's history provides content hashes, not actual revision ids. It is time-consuming when a repository has many revisions on the same path which have the same content.

The fix for this issue provides a  --Xenable-git-content-hash-resolving-heuristic command line argument which allows FishEye to guess the revision when several match, at the cost of sometimes having incorrect revision ids displayed on the File tab of the repository browse page.

See the screenshots below for details.

!20120315-rxp6rkq93md7gnpmx2q3nf1srf.jpg!

!20120315-dmxy4jwwuhsnf6ip6dkrnd2yf9.jpg!
fields.summary: Allow disabling of precise contentHash to csid mapping

fields.description:
If a user logs in with a username containing upper case characters, but the external auth system is case independent, they may get an error like:

com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.DbException: User named "djdch" already exists.
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.DefaultUserManager$19.write(DefaultUserManager.java:1251)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.DefaultUserManager$19.write(DefaultUserManager.java:1245)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.config.DB0Handle.write(DB0Handle.java:96)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.DefaultUserManager.addUserImpl(DefaultUserManager.java:1245)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.DefaultUserManager.importUser(DefaultUserManager.java:634)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.DefaultUserManager.getOrImportUser(DefaultUserManager.java:614)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.DefaultUserManager.loginWithSanitizedUserName(DefaultUserManager.java:432)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.DefaultUserManager.login(DefaultUserManager.java:407)
	at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor412.invoke(Unknown Source)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(Unknown Source)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Unknown Source)
	at org.springframework.aop.support.AopUtils.invokeJoinpointUsingReflection(AopUtils.java:309)
	at org.springframework.aop.framework.JdkDynamicAopProxy.invoke(JdkDynamicAopProxy.java:196)
	at $Proxy40.login(Unknown Source)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.web.LoginServlet.login(LoginServlet.java:108)

when they login.

This is because the initial check to see if the user exists uses the mixed case name, and FeCru is case sensitive, but the name used to create the user is that returned by the external auth, which is mapped to lower case.

We should always use the name provided by the user to create the local user, not the name returned by the external auth system, or should always map user names to lower case when external auth is used (which would probably not be backward compatible).
fields.summary: Case insensitive external auth systems cause problems, should be reported/avoided better

The documentation should make a distinction between the FishEye/Crucible versions, and give the appropriate instructions.

fields.description:
When in Fisheye there seems to be a problem with the Reports -> Review Coverage. Its possible to check the code committed and the reviews completed on the code. There are 2 buttons at the top of the screen, 'Week' and 'Day' it always seem to default to 'Day' and return details of the activities of the 'Day'. When you select 'Week' no additional information is returned and it does not seem possible to re-run the query (The 'Day' tab is still selected when the 'Week' option is selected also).

To Reproduce:
Log into Fisheye.
Select "Source" and a valid project from the list.
Select the "Reports" tab.
Select "Review Coverage"
fields.summary: Not possible to select 'Week' when running 'Review Coverage' in Fisheye
